choices.D: Disable mail delegation for the accounts.receivable@yourcompany.com account.
choices.B: Configure a Sender Policy Framework (SPF) record for your domain.
choices.E: Disable "Allow users to automatically forward incoming email to another address."
choices.C: Configure Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to authenticate email.
choices.A: Change the password for suspected compromised account accounts.receivable@yourcompany.com.

questions.question_text:
Several customers have reported receiving fake collection notices from your company. The emails were received from accounts.receivable@yourcompany.com, which is the valid address used by your accounting department for such matters, but the email audit log does not show the emails in question. You need to stop these emails from being sent.
What two actions should you take? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
If you don't add SPF records, you cant configure DKIM. This are bouth recomended practices for spoofing and phishing attacks
https://support.google.com/a/answer/33786?hl=en
https://support.google.com/a/answer/174124?hl=en

Selected Answer: BC
The emails are not send from the GW environment so the only way to stop it is to enforce antispoofing with DKIM and SPF
A is not correct because the audit logs proves the account is not used.

questions.question_text:
Your cyber security team has requested that all email destined for external domains be scanned for credit card numbers, and if found, the email must be encrypted using your cloud-based third-party encryption provider. You are responsible for configuring to meet this request.
What should you do?

choices.A: Create a content compliance rule on outbound mail and internal-sending mail using the predefined rule for credit card numbers, and add a custom header that your third-party encryption provider can scan for and encrypt.
choices.D: Create a content compliance rule on outbound mail using the predefined rule for credit card numbers, and check "Change route" to send to your third-party encryption provider to encrypt.
choices.C: Create a content compliance rule on outbound mail using the predefined rule for credit card numbers, and add a custom header that your third-party encryption provider can scan for and encrypt.
choices.B: Create a content compliance rule on outbound mail using the predefined rule for credit card numbers, and check "Encrypt message if not encrypted".

discussion.content:
in order to use third party encryption you have to use alternate route hence option D is correct answer for me

https://support.google.com/a/answer/3540538?hl=en
D - It is a third-party encryption provider, therefore the route must be change to divert emails identified to the service

Selected Answer: B
You can use employee IDs as a login challenge. Employee IDs are more difficult to guess and phish than other types of identity challenges. To use the employee ID login challenge, you need to make sure that IDs are associated with your users' accounts.
https://support.google.com/a/answer/6002699?hl=en

Selected Answer: B
Employee ID is a way to add 2 seconf security factor using a familiar number to the final user, making it more "friendly". ref: https://support.google.com/a/answer/6002699?hl=en

Selected Answer: B
It is not a well known option but Employee ID login challenge does exist, yes.

questions.question_text:
Your organization is concerned with the increasing threat of phishing attacks that may impact users. Leadership has declined to force-enable 2-Step verification.
You need to apply a security measure to prevent unauthorized access to user accounts.
What should you do?

choices.C: Decrease the Maximum User Session Length.
choices.D: Revoke token authorizations to external applications.

discussion.content: C is the correct answer. - You want to limit high risk only and Google Drive is specifically within that scope. https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en

Selected Answer: B
B for sure.
CISO said "third-party apps should not have OAuth permissions to Google Drive". It means "Restricted" in GWS.
https://support.google.com/a/answer/7281227?hl=en#zippy=%2Cmanage-third-party-app-access-to-google-services-add-apps%2Crestrict-or-unrestrict-google-services:~:text=(Optional)%20If%20you,for%20all%20apps.)
Without a doubt, the correct answer is C. You can verify by yourself from admin console Security>API Controls>App Access Control> choose Drive > Restrict Access to High Risk OAth scopes.
What would be the correct option?
C - option for high risk only
I will also go with option D

comments.content:
Nope, D is the correct one.
"Prevent people outside "domain" from accessing files in the shared drive"
D would prevent people from sharing files too.

questions.question_text:
Your company's Chief Information Security Officer has made a new policy where third-party apps should not have OAuth permissions to Google Drive. You need to reconfigure current settings to adhere to this policy.
What should you do?

choices.D: Access Apps > G Suite > Drive and Docs > Sharing Settings and disable sharing outside of your domain
choices.C: Access the Security Menu > API Permissions > choose Drive and Disable High Risk Access.
choices.B: Access the Security Menu > API Permissions > choose Drive and Disable All Access.
choices.A: Access the Security Menu> API Reference > disable all API Access.

choices.B: Review user-reported spam in the Investigation Tool.
choices.C: Review spike in user-reported spam in the Alert center.
choices.D: Review post-delivery activity in the BigQuery Export.
choices.A: Review post-delivery activity in the Email logs.

questions.question_text: How can you monitor increases in user reported Spam as identified by Google?

discussion.content: It is C for sure, the question says "as identified by Google", so the only option to understand if google has identified any spike in spam is alert center (analysing logs you make your own assumptions on what is a spike, it is not identifed by google)
Option C is the correct answer?

comments.content: C is correct, this link [https://support.google.com/a/answer/9104586?hl=en] shows that "Spike in user reported spam" is an Alert option available via the Alert Centre

discussion.content: C is correct. We are assuming that we aren't building a report through big query and these are generated alerts from Alert Center as stated by the question.
